then this is the crucial stage it must
be brought to a simmer but not allowed
to come to a rolling boil all right so
we're looking at it the first thing
you're going to notice is it heats up it

and then those bubbles get a little

and really you shouldn't be wondering

all right that's going to cook for eight
to 12 hours I'm a 12-hour guy some

hours
some people go eight hours there's all
kinds of theories I'm a 12-hour guy
that's how we always did it in the

it how you want every once in a while
I'd like to put in a small splash of

naturally I'd rather have a chicken

one that maybe over reduces I want

I'm going to turn it off and let it cool
I don't know for about an hour just like

extra pure come on you're why people

okay look how clear that is already it's

clear stock is not boiling the
impurities into it not and multiplying
any fat into it not having the
vegetables break up and dissolve and
boil into the stock that's why we want
this really gentle simmer now before we
put this in jars and put it in the
fridge we got to cool it down I'm going
to take a bowl of ice water put my bowl
of strain chicken stock on top and just
give it a stir and 15 minutes later
you're going to have a nice cool stock
which you could then put into mason jars
and keeping the refrigerator until
needed all right now keep in mind
there's no saltness there's no
preservatives so you're going to want to
use this pretty quickly within a couple
days or you're going to want to freeze
it you can put it in ziplock bags freeze
it some people freeze in ice cube trays
and then put into the block bags
whatever you're into so when I ladle
this in I like to put about a half inch
to a quarter inch of the fat on top that
actually makes an airtight seal so
anyway that's how you make chicken stock
